qas.question: What did the writer of a 1788 multi-volumed text say concerning plagiarism and the Roman Catholic Church ?

answers.text: The Latin Church has not disdained to borrow from the Koran the immaculate conception of his virgin mother

qas.question: Who is the author of the texts entailed in the fifth part of the the collection about the Roman Catholic Church ?
What was the group of volumes titled ?

answers.text: Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire

qas.question: Where does the author state that the Roman Catholic Church received her facts and confirmations ?
Who's doctrine does Islam derive its teachings from?

plausible_answers.text: volume 5 of his Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire

qas.question: What did St Bernard write in 1788?

plausible_answers.text: "The Latin Church has not disdained to borrow from the Koran the immaculate conception of his virgin mother."

qas.question: What charge did St Bernard repeat in 1854?

plausible_answers.text: the doctrine which the church of Rome has promulgated, with so much pomp and ceremony

qas.question: What has its origin in the Bible?

context: Further claims were made that the <b4_0>Roman Catholic Church<b4_0/> derives its doctrine from the Islamic teaching. In <b5_0>volume 5 of his <a2_0>Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire<b5_0/><a2_0/>, published in 1788, <a1_0>Edward Gibbon<a1_0/> wrote: <b6_0>"<a0_0>The Latin Church has not disdained to borrow from the Koran the immaculate conception of his virgin mother<a0_0/>."<b6_0/> That he was speaking of her immaculate conception by her mother, not of her own virginal conception of Jesus, is shown by his footnote: "In the xiith century the immaculate conception was condemned by St. Bernard as a presumptuous novelty." In the aftermath of the definition of the dogma in 1854, this charge was repeated: "Strange as it may appear, that <b7_0>the doctrine which the church of Rome has promulgated, with so much pomp and ceremony<b7_0/>, 'for the destruction of all heresies, and the confirmation of the faith of her adherents', should have its origin in the <a3_0>Mohametan Bible<a3_0/>; yet the testimony of such authorities as Gibbon, and Sale, and Forster, and Gagnier, and Maracci, leave no doubt as to the marvellous fact."
